etymologies: mid 19th century; earliest use found in Bessemer Process & Works in United States. From re- + carburization. Compare French recarburation

definitions: Originally: the addition of carbon (typically in the form of coke, anthracite, or a carbon-rich alloy) to steel following decarburization, in order to produce the desired degree of hardness and strength. Later also more widely: = recarbonization.
